case_vignette: A 51-year-old man presents complaining of decreased vibratory sense in his lower limbs. Physical exam reveals a widened pulse pressure and a decrescendo murmur occurring after the S2 heart sound. After further questioning, he also reports he experienced a maculopapular rash over his trunk, palms and soles many years ago that resolved on its own.
question: In order to evaluate the suspected diagnosis, the physician FIRST tested for which ?
correct_ans: agglutination of antibodies with beef cardiolipin

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I've noticed that I'm not feeling vibrations as well in my legs.

No changes in hearing or balance, just the sensation issue in my legs.
Have you noticed any changes in your vision or speech?
No, my vision and speech are normal.

No, my mood and energy levels have been the same.
Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight?
No, my appetite and weight have stayed the same.
Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns or quality?
No, my sleep has been normal.

No, my stress levels and workload have been consistent.

No new changes in my family's medical history.

No, there haven't been any new illnesses or changes in my medications recently.

No, my lifestyle habits have stayed the same.

No, my environment and work setting have not changed.

No, my daily routine and activities are the same as they've always been.
Have you noticed any changes in your overall health or wellness?
No overall changes in my health or wellness, just the issue with feeling vibrations in my legs.
Final Diagnosis: Peripheral Neuropathy.
